title: YNAP on track for de-listing after Richemont offer breaches threshold
text:
May 9, 2018 / 5:06 PM / Updated 42 minutes ago YNAP on track for de-listing after Richemont offer breaches threshold Reuters Staff 1 Min Read
MILAN (Reuters) - Online luxury retailer Yoox Net-a-Porter (YNAP) ( YNAP.MI ) is on track to be de-listed following the end of a takeover offer launched by Cartier owner Richemont ( CFR.S ), data from the Italian bourse showed on Wednesday. FILE PHOTO: Branding is seen on the clothing of an employee of online clothing retailer Yoox Net-A-Porter at their Tech Hub premises in White City in London, Britain June 27, 2017. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo
Richemont — which already owns 25 percent of YNAP — in January offered up to 2.8 billion euros (2.5 billion pounds) for full control of the retailer to better compete in an expanding online market for luxury goods.
Nearly 94 percent of the shareholders targeted by the offer - or around 70 percent of YNAP’s share capital - accepted the bid by its deadline, preliminary data from the Italian bourse showed, taking Richemont’s stake in the company to just above 95 percent.
That is above the 90-percent threshold that triggers an obligation to buy out the remaining investors and de-list the group. Reporting by Agnieszka Flak
